paths: Determine if the patient has eye pain or not -> Check the state of the pupil -> The pupil is unreactive and fixed in a mid-dilated position. -> Acute angle-closure glaucoma
Determine if the patient has eye pain or not -> Check the state of the pupil -> The pupil looks normal, but further evaluation shows a relative afferent pupillary defect (APD). -> Optic neuritis

Determine if the patient has eye pain or not -> Check for symptoms of giant cell arteritis -> Symptoms of giant cell arteritis include jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, headache, malaise, anorexia, and proximal joint or muscle aches. -> Symptoms of giant cell arteritis

Determine if the patient has eye pain or not -> Check for symptoms of giant cell arteritis -> Symptoms of retinal detachment include photopsias, floaters, and a curtain or shadow moving in the field of vision. -> Retinal detachment symptoms

Determine if the patient has eye pain or not -> Check for symptoms of giant cell arteritis -> Perform ophthalmoscopy -> On ophthalmoscopy, the infarcted retina appears whitish and opacified, with a cherry-red spot in the center of the macula. -> Central retinal artery occlusion

Determine if the patient has eye pain or not -> Check for symptoms of giant cell arteritis -> Perform ophthalmoscopy -> Ophthalmoscopic examination in central retinal vein occlusion reveals diffuse retinal hemorrhages, dilated retinal veins, and often cotton-wool spots. -> Central retinal vein occlusion

Determine if the patient has eye pain or not -> Check for symptoms of giant cell arteritis -> Perform ophthalmoscopy -> Patients with nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy -> Nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy
